Description: THE SUTTER NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE LIFT STATION PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A NEW WATER CONVEYANCE FACILITY THAT WILL PROVIDE IMPROVED ACCESS AND DELIVERY OF EXISTING WATER RIGHTS, AND ULTIMATELY IMPROVE THE CAPACITY AND RELIABILITY OF WATER DELIVERIES MADE UNDER THE AUSPICES OF THE CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT IMPROVEMENT ACT. THE PROJECT INVOLVES THE CONSTRUCTION OF A MULTI-MOTOR LIFT PUMP STATION EQUIPPED WITH FISH SCREENS, AND 800 FEET OF TRENCHED PIPELINE LEADING FROM THE PUMP STATION TO A NEW WATER DISTRIBUTION BASIN THAT WILL BE BUILT TO PROVIDE REFUGE STAFF THE MEANS FOR EFFICIENT DISPERSAL AND MANAGEMENT OF THE PUMPED WATER FOR EFFECTIVE WETLAND MANAGEMENT. THIS WILL IMPROVE OVERALL HABITAT CONDITIONS FOR WATERFOWL AND ALL THE OTHER MAJOR BIRD GROUPS UTILIZING SUTTER NATIONAL WILDLIFE  REFUGE. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE MIGRATORY WATERFOWL, SHOREBIRDS, AND WATERBIRDS  STATE AND FEDERALLY-LISTED SPECIES  OTHER WETLAND-DEPENDENT WILDLIFE  AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC. THE PUMP STATION WILL BE BUILT ON LAND OWNED BY THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA, WITH THE PLANNED PIPELINE TAKING THE PUMPED WATER FROM THE STATE LAND ONTO THE ADJACENT REFUGE. THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND U.S. BUREAU OF RECLAMATION ARE CONTINUING TO WORK ON A LONG-TERM SOLUTION FOR SUPPLYING CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT IMPROVEMENT ACT WATER TO SUTTER NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, FOR WHICH A MEANS OF CONVEYANCE DOES NOT CURRENTLY EXIST. THIS PROJECT WILL ULTIMATELY PROVIDE A RELIABLE MEANS OF DELIVERING WATER TO THE HABITAT UNITS ONCE THE CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT IMPROVEMENT ACT WATER IS SECURED AND CONVEYED TO THE REFUGE. AN INITIAL AWARD WAS MADE IN 2020 TO DUCKS UNLIMITED, INC. TO OVERSEE THE LIFT STATION CONSTRUCTION PROJECT AND THEY WILL EXECUTE, ADMINISTER, AND MANAGE ALL CONTRACTS SUBCONTRACTS THAT ARE NEEDED TO FULLY IMPLEMENT THE PROJECT INCLUDING SUPPORT SERVICES (E.G., LABOR COMPLIANCE AND SPECIAL-STATUS SPECIES SURVEYS AND MITIGATION) AND CONSTRUCTION. DUCKS UNLIMITED, INC. IS A VERY RELIABLE NON-GOVERNMENTAL CONSERVATION ORGANIZATION, INTERNATIONALLY RENOWNED FOR THEIR SUCCESSFUL WILDLIFE HABITAT RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT PROJECTS PERFORMED THROUGHOUT NORTH AMERICA FOR OVER 80 YEARS. HUNDREDS OF THESE PROJECTS HAVE DIRECTLY SUPPORTED REFUGES WITHIN THE NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE SYSTEM. THE PROJECT IS SPLIT INTO TWO PHASES. PHASE 1 (NON-CONSTRUCTION WORK) TOOK PLACE DURING MAY 2020 THROUGH SEPTEMBER 2022. PHASE 2 (CONSTRUCTION WORK) WILL TAKE PLACE DURING APRIL 2023 THROUGH SEPTEMBER 2024. IN PHASE 1 EXTENSIVE TIME WAS SPENT BY DUCKS UNLIMITED, INC. COMPLETING SUBSTANTIAL DESIGN WORK, INCLUDING THE REVIEW AND EDITING OF SEVERAL 100  FINAL DESIGNS SUBMITTED FROM U.S. BUREAU OF RECLAMATION  DAILY WORK ON REQUIRED CALIFORNIA ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY ACT DOCUMENTS, INCLUDING ASSISTING WITH THE EDITING OF A BIOLOGICAL ASSESSMENT AND AVOIDANCE MEASURES  A SIGNIFICANT AMOUNT OF COORDINATION WITH TRIBES AND TRIBAL LIAISONS IN SATISFYING SECTION 106 REQUIREMENTS  COORDINATING WITH THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS ON THE NECESSARY WRITING AND RENEWAL OF A SECTION 404 PERMIT  AND SECURING SUFFICIENT MITIGATION CREDITS FOR IMPACTS THE PROJECT WOULD HAVE TO THE FEDERALLY-LISTED GIANT GARTER SNAKE. MEANWHILE, U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE REALTY STAFF WORKED ON NEGOTIATING A LONG-TERM EASEMENT WITH THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA TO BUILD ON THELIFT STATION SITE  THOSE EFFORTS TOOK OVER A YEAR WITH THE PERPETUAL EASEMENT FINALLY RECORDED IN AUGUST 2022.

THERE IS LIMITED SPAWNING HABITAT AVAILABLE FOR SALMON NATURALLY SPAWNING IN THE FEATHER RIVER. OVER THE YEARS, SINCE THE OROVILLE DAM WAS BUILT, THE EXISTING HABITAT HAS DEGRADED AND MUCH OF THE SPAWNING AREAS NOW CONSIST OF PRIMARILY LESS THAN DESIRABLE LARGE COBBLE. THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF WATER RESOURCES  DWR  WILL USE FUNDING FROM THE CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT IMPROVEMENT ACT  CVPIA  TO PLAN, DESIGN, PERMIT, AND INSTALL APPROXIMATELY 12,000 CUBIC YARDS OF NEEDED SPAWNING GRAVEL INTO THE FEATHER RIVER. THIS SPAWNING GRAVEL WILL IMPROVE TWO OF THE MOST HIGHLY USED SPAWNING AREAS ON THE LOW FLOW SECTION OF THE FEATHER RIVER.THIS PROJECT WILL BE A CONTINUATION OF GRAVEL INSTALLATION WORK DONE BY DWR IN BOTH 2014 AND 2017 IN THE LOW FLOW SECTION AT HATCHERY RIFFLE. PREVIOUS WORK HAS SHOWN TO BE SUCCESSFUL AS THE SITES HAVE BEEN HEAVILY USED BY FALL-RUN CHINOOK SALMON, STEELHEAD  ESA THREATENED , AND SPRING-RUN CHINOOK SALMON  CESA AND ESA THREATENED  AFTER GRAVEL WAS PLACED.THIS SCOPE OF WORK INCLUDES PLANNING, DESIGN, MODELING AND PERMITTING TO CREATE A BID PACKAGE AND THEN HIRING A CONTRACTOR TO PROCURE AND INSTALL THE GRAVEL. THIS FUNDING WILL BE UTILIZED IN CONJUNCTION WITH CALIFORNIA PROPOSITION 68 GRANT FUNDS TO TAKE ADVANTAGE OF AN ECONOMY OF SCALE TO AND ALLOW GRAVEL AUGMENTATION IN MULTIPLE LOCATIONS.

IN THE CENTRAL VALLEY OF CALIFORNIA, THERE ARE FOUR DISTINCT RUNS OF CHINOOK SALMON (THE FALL, LATE FALL, WINTER, AND SPRING RUNS). THE JUVENILES OF THESE RUNS MIX TO VARIOUS DEGREES DURING THEIR SEAWARD MIGRATIONS THROUGH THE SACRAMENTO SAN JOAQUIN DELTA (THE  DELTA ). ESTIMATING THE JUVENILE ABUNDANCE OF THESE RUNS AS THEY ENTER THE DELTA AT SACRAMENTO AND EXIT THE DELTA AT CHIPPS ISLAND IS VIEWED BY THE SCIENTIFIC AND MANAGEMENT COMMUNITIES AS A CRITICAL ELEMENT IN IMPROVING INFORMATION FOR RESTORATION AND WATER MANAGEMENT IN THE DELTA. THIS IS ESPECIALLY TRUE FOR WINTER RUN, WHICH IS LISTED AS ENDANGERED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT.A MULTI YEAR, MULTI AGENCY PROJECT WAS INITIATED IN 2016 WITH THE GOAL OF DEVELOPING DATASETS AND STATISTICAL METHODS THAT WOULD ALLOW FOR THE RELIABLE ESTIMATION OF JUVENILE WINTER RUN ABUNDANCES AT TWO KEY MONITORING LOCATIONS  SACRAMENTO RIVER TRAWL (DELTA ENTRANCE) AND THE CHIPPS ISLAND TRAWL (DELTA EXIT). DURING YEARS 2016 2021, PROJECT DATA WERE COLLECTED FROM SEVERAL SOURCES  (1) PAIRED RELEASES OF ACOUSTIC TAGGED AND CODED WIRE TAGGED HATCHERY JUVENILES  (2) TRAWL CATCH AND EFFORT DATA  AND (3) TISSUE SAMPLES OF TRAWL CAUGHT JUVENILES USED TO DETERMINE GENETIC RUN TYPE. COLLECTIVELY, THESE DATA PROVIDE THE INFORMATION NEEDED TO DETERMINE TRAWL EFFICIENCY (I.E., THE PROPORTION OF MIGRATING JUVENILES CAPTURED BY TRAWLS), WHICH IS THEN USED TO ESTIMATE JUVENILE ABUNDANCE.THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS FINAL PHASE OF THE PROJECT IS TO FINALIZE THE STATISTICAL MODELS AND RESULTS USING ALL YEARS OF DATA. THE SPECIFIC PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE, IN COLLABORATION WITH COINVESTIGATORS, THE FOLLOWING  (1) COMPLETION OF TRAWL EFFICIENCY MODELING AND WINTER RUN ABUNDANCE ESTIMATION FOR SACRAMENTO TRAWL  (2) COMPLETION OF ANALYSES OF FISH MOVEMENT AT THE SACRAMENTO AND CHIPPS ISLAND TRAWL LOCATIONS BASED ON ACOUSTIC TAGGED JUVENILES  (3) COMPLETION OF ANALYSES TO DETERMINE POTENTIAL IMPROVEMENTS IN FUTURE DATA COLLECTION EFFORTS  AND (4) COMPLETION OF REPORTS AND PEER REVIEW MANUSCRIPTS DETAILING THE RESULTS AND CONCLUSIONS OF THE OVERALL PROJECT.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  SERVICE  SOLICITED PROPOSALS FOR THE COMPLETION OF A FEASIBILITY STUDY AND ALTERNATIVES ANALYSIS TO EVALUATE POTENTIAL ALTERNATIVE SOLUTIONS TO PROVIDE ADULT SALMONID FISH PASSAGE AT WEIR 1 IN THE BUTTE CREEK   SUTTER BYPASS WEST BORROW CANAL  WBC . THE CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT IMPROVEMENT ACT  CVPIA  SCIENCE INTEGRATION TEAM AND CORE TEAM RECOMMENDED IMPROVING ADULT AND JUVENILE PASSAGE ON BUTTE CREEK AND IDENTIFIED FISH PASSAGE AT WEIR 1 AS A HIGH PRIORITY FOR EVALUATION AND RESTORATION. WEIR 1 IS A COMBINED WEIR AND FISH LADDER STRUCTURE LOCATED IN THE WBC THAT IS IN DISREPAIR AND IS NOT FUNCTIONING FOR THE PURPOSES OF DIVERTING OR DELIVERING WATER. WEIR 1 IS LOCATED IMMEDIATELY UPSTREAM OF THE INTERSECTION OF THE TISDALE WEIR BYPASS WITH THE WEST LEVEE OF THE SUTTER BYPASS. BUTTE CREEK IS ONE OF THE MOST PRODUCTIVE SALMONID STREAMS IN THE SACRAMENTO RIVER VALLEY   UTILIZED BY FEDERAL- AND STATE-LISTED SPRING-RUN CHINOOK SALMON  SRCS . SRCS MIGRATE UP THE SUTTER BYPASS TO BUTTE CREEK, NAVIGATING PAST SEVERAL WATER CONTROL STRUCTURES TO ACCESS SPAWNING AREAS IN THE UPPER BUTTE CREEK SYSTEM. IN TURN, JUVENILE SALMON REVERSE THIS ROUTE DURING OUTMIGRATION TO THE PACIFIC OCEAN. THE MIGRATION OF ANADROMOUS FISH, WHICH INCLUDES  FALL- AND SPRING-RUN  CHINOOK SALMON AND CENTRAL VALLEY STEELHEAD, IS IMPEDED BY WEIR 1. THE CVPIA ANADROMOUS FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM FUNDED ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE ASSOCIATED  ESA  TO COMPLETE THE FEASIBILITY STUDY AND ALTERNATIVES ANALYSIS. ESA WILL CONDUCT DATA COLLECTION  COMPLETE CONCEPTUAL DESIGN DEVELOPMENT FOR FOUR ALTERNATIVES INCLUDING COST ESTIMATION  CONVENE, FACILITATE, AND WORK WITH A TECHNICAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE  ASSESS A SET OF ALTERNATIVES INCLUDING EVALUATION WITH A HYDRODYNAMIC MODEL  AND SUPPORT THE EVALUATION OF THE ALTERNATIVES TO ALLOW THE SERVICE AND PROJECT MANAGEMENT TEAM TO IDENTIFY A PREFERRED ALTERNATIVE SOLUTION FOR FISH PASSAGE AT WEIR 1.THE PROJECT TIMELINE IS ANTICIPATED TO RUN 12 MONTHS FROM OCTOBER 2022 THROUGH SEPTEMBER 2023  FISCAL YEAR 2023 .
PHASE II OF THE LOWER STANISLAUS RIVER MIGRATORY CORRIDOR PROJECT   DEVELOPMENT OF THE BUFFINGTON TRACT SALMONID HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECT

DESPITE MAINTAINING FEDERALLY ENDANGERED STATUS FOR OVER 50 YEARS, THE BLUNT NOSED LEOPARD LIZARD S POPULATION HAS CONTINUED TO DECLINE  THESE DECLINES ARE DIRECTLY ASSOCIATED WITH LAND CONVERSION TO IRRIGATED AGRICULTURE, IN PART FROM THE CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT  IN PARTICULAR, THE NORTHERN POPULATIONS, WHICH ARE GENETICALLY DISTINCT FROM SOUTHERN POPULATIONS, ARE RAPIDLY DISAPPEARING, WITH 50  OF KNOWN NORTHERN POPULATIONS DISAPPEARING WITHIN THE LAST 30 YEARS  THE ONLY NORTHERN POPULATION ON FEDERAL LAND OCCURS ON THE PANOCHE PLATEAU, AND THIS POPULATION HAS DECLINED RAPIDLY OVER THE LAST FIVE YEARS  DESPITE INTENSIVE FIELD EFFORTS IN 2020, ONLY NINE ADULT ANIMALS WERE FOUND ON THE PANOCHE PLATEAU AND THIS NUMBER DWINDLED TO FIVE BY THE END OF THE REPRODUCTIVE SEASON  IN RESPONSE TO THIS RAPID COLLAPSE, THE FRESNO CHAFFEE ZOO, UNITED STATES BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, AND FRESNO STATE UNIVERSITY INITIATED A COLLABORATIVE PARTNERSHIP IN CONSULTATION WITH PARTNERS AT THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE TO PROPAGATE AND REINTRODUCE BLUNT NOSED LEOPARD LIZARDS TO THE PANOCHE PLATEAU  WE WERE GRANTED EMERGENCY PERMISSION TO COLLECT THE LAST FIVE ADULT ANIMALS FROM THE POPULATION TO SERVE AS FOUNDERS FOR CAPTIVE BREEDING AT FRESNO CHAFFEE ZOO IN JULY 2020  THESE ANIMALS ARE CURRENTLY THRIVING AT FRESNO CHAFFEE ZOO AND ARE ALREADY REPRODUCING  OUR GOAL IS TO MAINTAIN A COLONY OF 20 BREEDING PAIRS AND REINTRODUCE ANIMALS WHEN THEY ARE APPROXIMATELY NINE MONTHS OF AGE  ALL REINTRODUCED ANIMALS WILL BE RADIO COLLARED AND MONITORED THROUGHOUT THEIR FIRST SEASON TO ASSESS REINTRODUCTION SUCCESS  REINTRODUCTION WILL CONTINUE UNTIL E 50 NATURAL BORN FEMALES REPRODUCE FOR THREE CONSECUTIVE YEARS  THE FRESNO CHAFFEE ZOO WILL PARTNER WITH THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND THE UNITED STATES BUREAU OF RECLAMATION TO CONSTRUCT A CONSERVATION FACILITY ON THE ZOO PROPERTY  THIS BUILDING WILL BE UTILIZED TO HOUSE THE BLUNT NOSED LEOPARD LIZARD BREEDING PROGRAM, IN ADDITION, THIS BUILDING WILL ALLOW OUR HIGHLY QUALIFIED CARE AND RESEARCH STAFF TO PROVIDE EXCELLENT CARE FOR THE LIZARD POPULATION  THIS FACILITY WILL HAVE PUBLIC VIEWING WINDOWS, PROVIDE INTERPRETATIVE INFORMATION, AND VIDEO MONITORS, WHICH WILL PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY TO CONNECT FRESNO CHAFFEE ZOO VISITORS WITH THE CONSERVATION EFFORTS AND REINTRODUCTION PROCESS OF THIS ENDANGERED SPECIES  IN ADDITION TO BEING VITAL TO THE SUCCESS OF THE BLUNT NOSED LEOPARD LIZARD REINTRODUCTION PROGRAM, THIS NEW BUILDING WILL SUPPORT LONG TERM CONSERVATION EFFORTS WITHIN THE SAN JOAQUIN VALLEY AREA, AS WELL AS OTHER VITAL CONSERVATION PROJECTS FAR INTO THE FUTURE  CONSTRUCTION OF THIS FACILITY WILL BE ANTICIPATED TO BE COMPLETED BY DECEMBER 31, 2023  CONTRACTS FOR CONSTRUCTION HAVE NOT YET BEEN SELECTED, HOWEVER, FRESNO CHAFFEE ZOO LOOKS FORWARD TO WORKING WITH MANY LOCAL TRADES

THE PROJECT RESTORATION PHASE ASSUMES DEGRADED, OR IN ACCESSIBLE HABITAT IS PRESENT, AND IN SUFFICIENT QUANTITY OR SCALE TO SUPPORT EFFECTIVE REMEDIATION EFFORTS  IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT ASSUMES NON NATAL STREAMS INUNDATE SEASONALLY, PRODUCING AN ACTIVE CHANNEL FROM PERENNIAL  WINTER  RUN OFF EVENTS OF MEASURABLE DISCHARGE, VOLUME, AND DURATION SUFFICIENT FOR SUPPORTING MIGRATION OF SALMONIDS  OR OTHER NATIVE NON NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES  AT BOTH JUVENILE AND ADULT LIFE STAGES  THE DATA GATHERED DURING THE STUDY PHASE OF THE PROJECT WILL SERVE AS THE BASIS FOR RESTORATION ACTIONS  IF DEGRADED OR INACCESSIBLE HABITAT IS FOUND, RESTORATION MEASURES AND PHASE TWO ACTIONS FOR HABITAT ALTERATIONS IMPROVEMENTS WILL BE AGREED UPON BY A PANEL OF SCIENTISTS AND MANAGERS  IF SALMONID MIGRATION IS IMPINGED OR REARING CONDITIONS ARE FOUND TO BE CONFOUNDED BY NATURAL OR ANTHROPOCENTRIC SOURCES, STRATEGIES WILL BE EXPLORED FOR RESTORING CONNECTIVITY TO UPSTREAM OR OFF CHANNEL LOCATIONS WHERE POTENTIAL SUITABLE HABITAT EXIST  THE TARGET STUDY STREAMS IN YEAR 1 MAY INCLUDE DYE, SALT, TOOMES CREEKS IN TEHAMA COUNTY AND CHURN, DRY AND STILLWATER CREEKS IN SHASTA COUNTY

INTERIOR S EFFORT TO ADDRESSES THE CVPIA DIRECTIVE TO DOUBLE NATURAL PRODUCTION OF ANADROMOUS FISH WITHIN CENTRAL VALLEY RIVERS AND STREAMS THROUGH THE ANADROMOUS FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM  AFRP   USFWS RECOGNIZES THE NEED FOR ASSISTANCE TO HANDLE THE WORKLOAD AND TO INCREASE COORDINATION WITH THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, THE STATE AGENCY WITH PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY FOR RESTORATION OF ANADROMOUS FISH HABITAT THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FUNDS THREE SENIOR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTIST  SPECIALIST , ONE EACH IN CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE  CDFW  REGIONS 1, 2 AND 4, TO ACT AS HABITAT RESTORATION COORDINATORS  HRCS   IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AFRP STAFF, AND AS MUTUALLY AGREED TO BETWEEN THE AFRP PROGRAM MANAGER AND THE APPROPRIATE CDFW REGIONAL MANAGER  HRCS ACT AS ACTION MANAGERS FOR THOSE PROJECTS AND EVALUATIONS THAT ARE WITHIN THEIR ASSIGNED AREA, TO ASSIST IN THE PREPARATION OF APPROPRIATE PLANS AND ENVIRONMENTAL DOCUMENTS, SECURE APPROPRIATE PERMITS, ENSURING ALL CONTRACTS ARE PROPERLY APPROVED, WORKING WITH PARTNERS AND CONTRACTORS TO ENSURE LEGAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE, INSPECT IN PROGRESS AND COMPLETED CONSTRUCTION, AND WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR ALL OTHER ASPECTS OF PROJECT MANAGEMENT  HRCS WILL ASSIST LOCAL WATERSHED WORKGROUPS, PRIVATE AND PUBLIC LANDOWNERS, AND OTHER PARTNERS IN IDENTIFYING AND DEVELOPING HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIONS AND PLANNING DOCUMENTS  COORDINATE CLOSELY WITH LOCAL LANDOWNERS AND WATERSHED WORKGROUPS BY PROVIDING ASSISTANCE, IDENTIFYING FUNDING, REVIEWING PLANNING DOCUMENTS, ASSISTING CONSULTANTS, AND PROVIDING OTHER TECHNICAL EXPERTISE  HRCS SERVE AS THE CDFW AND AFRP REPRESENTATIVE ON VARIOUS LOCAL WATERSHED WORKGROUPS AND OTHER COMMITTEES RELATED TO ANADROMOUS FISH RESTORATION

GENETIC MANAGEMENT OF HATCHERY PRODUCTION OF DELTA SMELT FOR SUPPLEMENTATION OF THE WILD POPULATION WILL REQUIRE AN EFFICIENT CROSS SELECTION APPROACH THAT CAN SCALE WITH ESCALATING DEMANDS ON GENETIC AND PRODUCTION MANAGEMENT  THE CURRENT CROSS SELECTION METHOD USES A TIME CONSUMING, DIFFICULT, AND ERROR PRONE PROCESS THAT WAS DESIGNED FOR SMALL SCALE PRODUCTION OF A GENETICALLY MANAGED REFUGE POPULATION  THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP AN EFFICIENT CROSS SELECTION SOFTWARE APPLICATION THAT IS ADAPTABLE TO INCREASED, GENETICALLY MANAGED PRODUCTION OF DELTA SMELT FOR SUPPLEMENTATION  THE SOFTWARE APPLICATION WILL BE ABLE TO RAPIDLY SUGGEST VERY LARGE NUMBERS OF CROSSES FOR BREEDING  IT ALSO WILL REMOVE THE NEED FOR HUMAN DETERMINATION OF PREFERRED CROSSES AND WILL RETAIN INFORMATION ABOUT HISTORICAL CROSSES  THE APPLICATION WILL SUGGEST CROSSES BASED ON I  MAINTAINING GENETIC DIVERSITY WITHIN THE POPULATION BY CONTROLLING THE EFFECTIVE NUMBER OF BREEDERS AND II  MAINTAINING HIGHEST PROBABILITIES OF VIABLE OFFSPRING BY CONTROLLING THE LEVEL OF INBREEDING  BY RETAINING CAPTIVE POPULATION CHARACTERISTICS DATA AS WELL AS BREEDING RESULTS, THE APPLICATION WILL BE ABLE TO ANALYZE AND REPORT ON BREEDING SUCCESS  ACCESS TO GENOTYPE DATA IN THE SOFTWARE ALSO WILL FACILITATE MONITORING AND MODELING OF GENETIC EFFECTS OF SUPPLEMENTATION

PURPOSE:THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO SUPPORT THE CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT IMPROVEMENT ACT ANADROMOUS FISH DOUBLING GOAL THROUGH THE MONITORING OF ANADROMOUS FISH POPULATIONS IN TWO KEY CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT WATERSHEDS - THE AMERICAN AND STANISLAUS RIVERS. THIS POPULATION DATA INFORMS RIVERINE HABITAT RESTORATION AND WATER FLOW MANAGEMENT IN THESE WATERSHEDS. THE AMERICAN PEOPLE ARE BENEFICIARIES OF THIS AWARD.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:THE CONTRACTOR SHALL PROVIDE SERVICES FOR THE COLLECTION, RECORDING, ANALYSIS, AND REPORTING OF RST DATA ON THE AMERICAN AND STANISLAUS RIVERS. AS TRAPPING OCCURS, A COMPLETE RANGE OF BIOLOGICAL, OPERATIONAL, AND ENVIRONMENTAL DATA ON JUVENILE SALMON AND OTHER SPECIES INCIDENTALLY CAPTURED SHALL BE COLLECTED AS DESCRIBED IN THE AMERICAN RIVER ROTARY SCREW TRAP PROJECT PROTOCOL.THE FIELD WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED BETWEEN LATE-DECEMBER THROUGH MID-TO-LATE JUNE OF THE FOLLOWING YEAR.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: A 1-2-PAGE WRITTEN PROPOSAL GENERALLY DESCRIBING HOW AND WHEN THE CONTRACTOR WILL CONDUCT ALL OPERATIONAL ACTIVITIES DURING THE FIELD SEASON IS DUE WITHIN 60 DAYS PRIOR TO THE START OF THE FIELD SEASON.TWO-TO-THREE PAGE SUMMARIES SHALL BE PRODUCED MONTHLY, AND GENERALLY DESCRIBE FIELD ACTIVITIES AND TEMPORAL CHANGES IN DAILY SALMON CATCH. A DIGITAL COPY OF THE CAMP RST PLATFORM DATABASE IS DUE WITHIN 90 DAYS OF THE END OF THE FIELD SEASON WITH THE ORIGINAL PAPER DATASHEETS IN A BINDER.A DRAFT OF THE ANNUAL REPORT WILL BE DUE WITHIN 90 DAYS OF THE END OF A FIELD SEASON. THE FINAL ANNUAL REPORT WILL BE DUE WITHIN 30 DAYS FOLLOWING THE CAMP PROGRAM MANAGER'S TRANSMITTAL OF THEIR REVIEW COMMENTS ON THE DRAFT ANNUAL REPORT TO THE CONTRACTOR.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL ANALYZE ~281 OLOITHS COLLECTED IN BATTLE CREEK FROM 2001 TO 2020 TO DETERMINE HABITAT USE AND MIGRATORY PATTERNS OF BATTLE CREEK SPRING-RUN CHINOOK SALMON. RESULTS WILL LEVERAGE SIMILAR DATA SETS FROM BUTTE, MILL, AND DEER CREEKS TO SYNTHESIZE HOW CALIFORNIA CENTRAL VALLEY'S ESA-LISTED SPRING-RUN CHINOOK SALMON POPULATIONS USE NATAL TRIBUTARY, SACRAMENTO RIVER MAINSTEM, FLOODPLAIN, AND DELTA HABITATS ACROSS HYDROLOGIC REGIMES. FURTHER EVIDENCE FOR THE REESTABLISHMENT OF A SELF-SUSTAINING BATTLE CREEK SPRING-RU POPULATION CAN BE USED AS A GUIDE FOR SUCCESS OF THE BATTLE CREEK RESTORATION AREA AS WELL AS FUTURE REINTRODUCTION EFFORTS IN OTHER WATERSHEDS.

THE INFORMATION COLLECTED DURING REDD DEWATERING MONITORING WILL BE USED TO DETERMINE THE QUANTITY AND PERCENTAGE OF CHINOOK SALMON REDDS THAT ARE IN DANGER OF DEWATERING AND RELAY THIS INFORMATION TO GOVERNMENT MANAGERS IN REAL TIME AND ENUMERATE REDDS THAT HAVE BEEN DEWATERED. THE INFORMATION COLLECTED DURING SALMONID STRANDING EFFORTS WILL IDENTIFY AND CATEGORIZE AND DESCRIBE STANDING SITES AND RELOCATE, WHERE POSSIBLE, STRANDED SALMONIDS IN LOCATIONS WHERE THEIR SURVIVAL IS IN JEOPARDY. INFORMATION COLLECTED FROM THIS MONITORING WILL ALLOW AGENCY RESOURCE MANAGERS TO MAKE REAL-TIME DECISIONS REGARDING FLOW FLUCTUATION IMPACTS TO SALMONID MANAGEMENT AND TO REDUCE THESE IMPACTS TO FISH IF THEY OCCUR.

TROUT UNLIMITED DEER CREEK RED BLUFF TRICIA / ANADROMOUS FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM. THIS FUNDING WILL SUPPORT A PROJECT TO IMPROVE DOWNSTREAM JUVENILE AND UPSTREAM ADULT SALMONID MIGRATION AT STANFORD VINA RANCH IRRIGATION COMPANY⿿S (SVRIC) DIVERSION DAM IN DEER CREEK, TEHAMA COUNTY, CALIFORNIA.

THIS PROJECT WILL COMPLETE ONE PORTION OF THE DEER CREEK SVRIC FISH PASSAGE IMPROVEMENT PROJECT. THIS CURRENT CONDITIONS ASSESSMENT WILL DEVELOP INCLUDE INFORMATION ON HYDROLOGIC, GEOTECHNICAL, SLOPE STABILITY, HYDRAULIC, GEOMORPHIC, SEDIMENT TRANSPORT AND A FISH PASSAGE ASSESSMENT. DEER CREEK IS A TRIBUTARY TO THE UPPER SACRAMENTO RIVER NEAR VINA, CALIFORNIA, IN SOUTHEASTERN TEHAMA COUNTY. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE UNIMPEDED FISH PASSAGE FOR SALMONIDS IN THE LOWER DEER CREEK WATERSHED WHILE ALSO MEETING THE DIVERSION REQUIREMENTS OF THE DIVERSION ENTITY.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) SUPPORTS THIS WORK BEING DONE AS IT SUPPORTS OUR GOALS AND OBJECTIVES TO RESTORE HABITAT FOR NATURALLY REPRODUCING SALMONIDS. IT ALSO SUPPORTS RECOVERY OF THREE SPECIES LISTED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT OF 1973 (16 U.S.C. 1531-1543). FISH PASSAGE ON DEER CREEK IN TEHAMA COUNTY IS A HIGH PRIORITY FOR THE CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT IMPROVEMENT ACT (CVPIA) AND THE ANADROMOUS FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM (CFDA 15.648).

THE PARTNERSHIP TO WORK ON PRIVATE LAND AT THIS PRIVATE IRRIGATION DIVERSION (STREAM MILE 5) HAS BEEN DEVELOPED BY STATE AND FEDERAL FISH BIOLOGISTS OVER SEVERAL YEARS THROUGH THE BEGINNINGS OF ENGAGEMENT WITH LANDOWNERS, DIVERSION OWNERS AND TECHNICAL TEAM PROCESSES. THE LEAD PARTNER IS TROUT UNLIMITED WHO OBTAINED FUNDING IN SUMMER 2017 THROUGH CALIFORNIA⿿S PROPOSITION ONE (I.E. PROJECT 36310) AND LEVERAGED IT WITH THIS FUNDING FROM THE CVPIA ANADROMOUS FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM.
ESA - POST PROJECT MONITORING AT YUBA RIVER CANYON RESTORATION SITE
RED BLUFF FWO - MILL CREEK NOTCH WARD DAM FISH LADDER

1. REARING HABITAT AVAILABILITY AND DEFICIT ON THE LOWER YUBA RIVER
2. GENETIC ANALYSIS OF CHINOOK SALMON IN THE LOWER YUBA RIVER
3. ANADROMY IN O.MYKISS AND ITS RELATIONSHIP TO FLOW AND TEMPERATURE IN THE YUBA RIVER

SACRAMENTO WATER FORUM

BUTTONBUSH PARK RESTORATION PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT POST-PROJECT MONITORING AND EVALUATION OF THE BUTTONBUSH RESTORATION PROJECT ON THE STANISLAUS RIVER. MONITORING MAY INCLUDE, BUT IS NOT LIMITED TO TRAPPING AND TAGGING JUVENILE SALMONIDS, TOPOGRAPHIC SURVEYS, MACROINVERTEBRATE SURVEYS, AND WATER QUALITY ASSESSMENT. REVEGETATION MAY ALSO BE IMPLEMENTED.

EBMUD MOKELUMNE RIVER RIPARIAN DIVERSION SCREENING
THE FUNDING OPPORTUNITY IS TO MODIFY AND/OR SCREEN THE THREE HIGHEST PRIORITY DIVERSIONS ON THE LOWER MOKELUMNE RIVER (HAVING LANDOWNER SUPPORT) WITH APPROPRIATE MATERIALS. COSTS MAY INCLUDE PROJECT DESIGN, CONSTRUCTION, FISH SCREENS, PUMPS, CLEANING SYSTEMS, AND SITE-WORK. IN-KIND SUPPORT WILL BE PROVIDED BY EBMUD TO PREPARE ENVIRONMENTAL DOCUMENTATION AND PERMITTING FOR THE PROJECTS, AND CONDUCT PRE AND POST-PROJECT MONITORING.
